value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">29</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early writing</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">an impersonality, a generality. It gave us the 
            <choice>
              <sic>ballds</sic>
              <corr>ballads</corr>
            </choice>;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it gave us the songs. It allowed us to know 
            <choice>
              <sic>notning</sic>
              <corr>nothing</corr>
            </choice> of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">writer; and so to concentrate upon his song. <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> had</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great 
            <choice>
              <sic>privilges</sic>
              <corr>privileges</corr>
            </choice>. He was not responsible. He was not self</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">conscious. He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">repeat. He can say what every one feels. No 
            <choice>
              <sic>ne</sic>
              <corr>one</corr>
            </choice> tries to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">stamp his own name, to 
            <choice>
              <sic>disover</sic>
              <corr>discover</corr>
            </choice> his own 
            <choice>
              <sic>expereince</sic>
              <corr>experience</corr>
            </choice>, in his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">work. He keeps at a distance from the present moment.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Anon the lyric poet repeats over and over again</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that flowers fade; that death is the 
            <choice>
              <sic>ned</sic>
              <corr>end</corr>
            </choice>. He is 
            <choice>
              <sic>nver</sic>
              <corr>never</corr>
            </choice> tired</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of celebrating red roses and white breasts. The anonymous</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">playwright has like the singer this 
            <choice>
              <sic>namless</sic>
              <corr>nameless</corr>
            </choice> vitality,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">something drawn from the crowd in the penny seats and not yet</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">dead in ourselves. We can still become anonymous and forget</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">something that we have learnt when we read the plays to which</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">no one has troubled to set a name.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But at 
            <choice>
              <sic>asome</sic>
              <corr>some</corr>
            </choice> point there comes a break when anonymity</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">withdraws. Does it come when the playwright has absorbed</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the 
            <choice>
              <sic>contrbution</sic>
              <corr>contribution</corr>
            </choice> of the audience; and can return to them</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">their own general life in <add hand="typewriter" place="above">
            <choice>
              <sic>indivisualised</sic>
              <corr>individualised</corr>
            </choice></add> single and separate figures?</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmxmxmmmxxmxmxmx <add hand="ms" place="above">the complete [figure?] the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fals" key="Falstaff">Falstaff</rs>, the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-haml" key="Hamlet">Hamlet</rs></add> There comes a 
            <choice>
              <sic>mpoint</sic>
              <corr>point</corr>
            </choice> when the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">audience is no longer master of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>palaywright</sic>
              <corr>playwright</corr>
            </choice>. Yet he is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not separate from them. A common life still unites them;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">but there are moments of 
            <choice>
              <sic>seapaeation</sic>
              <corr>separation</corr>
            </choice>. Now we say, he is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>spaeking</sic>
              <corr>speaking</corr>
            </choice> our own 
            <choice>
              <sic>thoghts</sic>
              <corr>thoughts</corr>
            </choice>. Now thxmxmxmxmxmxmxxxx he is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">our 
            <choice>
              <sic>slves</sic>
            </choice>. But <add hand="ms" place="above">then</add> this sense of 
            <choice>
              <sic>indivi uality</sic>
              <corr>individuality</corr>
            </choice> comes fitfully.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The beauty which is so <del hand="typewriter">frequent and</del> 
            <choice>
              <sic>astoinshingly</sic>
              <corr>astonishingly</corr>
            </choice></l>
